Award.AwardTitle: Graph minors, topological minors, and immersions
Award.AbstractNarration:
A central area in combinatorics is the study of properties of graphs without certain substructures. This project addresses substructures with respect to three closely related graph containment relations: minors, topological minors, and immersions. Problems related to these containment relations have been proposed since more than 70 years ago. Great successes about graph minors were obtained during recent decades and led to numerous applications to disciplines other than combinatorics, such as theoretical computer science, electrical engineering and biology. However, several problems about graph minors and their strengthening or variations with respect to topological minors and immersions remain unsolved. This project addresses major conjectures in this area. Positive solutions will lead to immediate applications in theoretical computer science and optimization. More potential applications are expected based on fruitful applications of earlier work about graph minors. This project includes plenty of research problems that are suitable for graduate students and advanced undergraduate students.

Topics addressed in this project including graph coloring, Erdos-Posa property, well-quasi-ordering and general structural properties. One objective of this project is to solve or at least make significant progress on a group of questions about variations or relaxations of Hadwiger's conjecture on coloring graphs with no large clique minor, topological minor or immersion. Another objective is to prove a relationship between the maximum size of half-integral packing of topological minors and the minimum size of hitting sets, which is a strengthening of Thomas' conjecture on half-integral packing minors. Furthermore, Nash-Williams' conjecture on well-quasi-ordering graphs by the strong immersion relation will be considered. The strategies for attacking these conjectures are proving new structure theorems for excluding a fixed graph with respect to these three containment relations and exploiting tools that were developed in the PI's earlier work and in the literature for solving problems about graph minors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Graphs are useful models in science and engineering. This project studies graphs by studying relationships between graph structures and graph properties. The graph structures considered in is project are described by four closely related graph containment relations: minor, topological minor, weak immersion and strong immersion.These containments have been widely studied for decades, and they have been used to connect different research areas, such as graph theory, theoretical computer science, combinatorial optimization, and logic. However, many problems about these four containments remain open. Work in this project solves or makes significant progress for many of them. This project provides research opportunities to students and benefits outreach programs aimed at K-12 students and undergraduate students.

One kind of problems solved in this project is about structural descriptions of graphs that do not contain certain substructures with respect to one of those containment relations. It was showed in this project that those graphs can be decomposed into graphs that are more or less simpler than the substructures that they forbid.

Those decomposition theorems were later used in this project to prove nearly optimal results about clustered coloring. Those problems are weakenings of famous conjectures on graph coloring proposed since the 1940s. They ask for the minimum number of required parts in a partition of a graph with no certain substructures into induced subgraphs with no large components. Tight or nearly tight bounds for the number of required parts under assumptions about minor, topological minor or weak immersion were proved in this project.

Those decomposition theorems were also used in this project to solve Erdos-Posa type problems which are related to combinatorial optimization. The Erdos-Posa property grasps the cases when the optimal solutions of the packing problem and the covering problem are tied to each other, where these two problems can be formulated as a pair of dual integer programming problems whose solutions are not necessarily tied to each other in general. One result proved in this project implies a conjecture of Thomas about the Erdos-Posa property for packing and covering topological minors or minors when the packing is allowed to be half-integral. Another result proved in this project shows that the Erdos-Posa property holds for packing and covering weak immersions when the host graphs cannot be separated by deleting only a small number of edges.

Another direction in this project addresses well-quasi-ordering. It is a notion motivated by conjectures proposed in the 1940s and is extensively studied in graph theory and logic. Results about well-quasi-ordering proved in this project include a special case of a conjecture of Robertson about a topological minor analog of the famous Graph Minor Theorem and a directed graph version of Nash-Williams' conjecture for strong immersion.

Another result proved in this project is about cycle lengths in graphs. It solves a number of conjectures proposed since the 1980s, including a conjecture of Thomassen, a conjecture of Dean, and a conjecture of Sudakov and Verstraete, and provides the optimal answer of a question of Bondy and Vince. This project also solves a problem proposed by Fujiwara and Papasoglu about asymptotic dimension of metric spaces defined by minor-closed families, leading to applications in geometric group theory and coarse geometry.

Results obtained in this project enrich the outreach programs organized in the PI's department and the graduate courses taught by the PI. The PI gave talks and led activities in events aimed at K-12 students and undergraduate students, including underrepresented minorities, based on simplifications of some of those results. Those activities become templates and can be reused in the future. Results obtained in this project were presented in international and domestic conferences and seminars to promote collaboration and interaction with the research community.
